items.title: The Nintendo Switch 2 will be available in-store at Best Buy on July 1st
items.author: Brandon Russell
items.summary:
- The Nintendo Switch 2, launched on June 5th, will be available at Best Buy stores across *45 US states* starting July 1st, easing difficulty in acquiring the console.  
- It has become the *fastest-selling console* ever, with over 3.5 million units sold in four days, featuring a 7.9-inch 1080p display, magnetic Joy-Cons, and improved performance.  
- The Switch 2 standalone system is priced at *$449.99*, with a bundle including *Mario Kart World* costing *$499.99*, plus various accessories available through major retailers.

items.title: I tested a bunch of Switch 2 screen protectors, and these are the best
The government’s Apple antitrust lawsuit is still on
Netflix teams up with NASA to show live rocket launches and spacewalks
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- NASA Plus, launched in November 2023, offers live rocket launches, spacewalks, and stunning views of Earth from the ISS, now accessible on Netflix starting this Summer.
- This partnership makes NASA’s *science and exploration* content more *accessible* to Netflix's global audience of over 700 million, while remaining ad-free and free of additional cost.
- NASA Plus content will still be available for free on NASA’s website and through its app, ensuring a non-exclusive distribution strategy across *multiple platforms*.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg announces his AI ‘superintelligence’ super-group
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the creation of the Meta Superintelligence Labs, headed by Alexandr Wang, to advance AI research.  
- The group includes former industry leaders and new AI hires from Anthropic, Google DeepMind, and OpenAI, with aggressive hiring strategies involving eight-figure offers.  
- Meta plans to start research on next-generation AI models and explored acquisitions of various AI labs, though no formal offers have yet been made.

items.title: Jackery’s capable, solar-powered generator is nearly half off
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- *Jackery’s Explorer 1000 Power Station V2* offers 1,500 watts output, can power small appliances, and charges multiple devices simultaneously, making it ideal for camping with modern comforts.  
- The package includes a *SolarSaga 200W Portable Solar Panel* that recharges the generator in about 7.5 hours and can be improved to half the time with a second panel.  
- Currently available for $698.99 on Amazon, this is the *lowest price ever* and includes features like an app for monitoring battery status and an Emergency Charging mode for faster recharge.

items.title: Microsoft Authenticator Ends Password Autofill Support
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Microsoft Authenticator will stop supporting password storage and autofill starting July, directing users to Microsoft Edge or other password managers.  
- Saved payment information will be deleted in July, and passwords in August, with automatic syncing of passwords to Microsoft Edge offered.  
- Authenticator will continue supporting *passkeys* for device-based authentication, while focusing password autofill features within Edge for improved management.

items.title: Date Everything: A Romantic Comedy with Political Edge
items.author: Ash Parrish
items.summary:
*Date Everything* subverts expectations with its *deep exploration of human relationships* and *sharp political satire.*
- It features voice-acted characters of diverse backgrounds and inclusive content warnings.
- The game combines humor, adult themes, and clever dialogue, offering a unique twist on the dating sim genre.

  **Scores:** {"scale": 8, "impact": 7, "novelty": 8, "longTermSignificance": 6}
- *Keywords:* dating sim, political satire, voice acting, diversity, humor

items.title: What’s on your desk, Kallie Plagge?
Insta360 Link 2 Webcam Now $50 Off with Advanced Tracking
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- The *Insta360 Link 2* is an affordable ($149.99) 4K webcam with a motorized three-axis gimbal that *actively tracks user movements*, keeping presenters centered during calls or streams.
- It features *AI-powered framing*, allowing automatic zoom and multi-presenter tracking, with customizable no-follow zones to control camera focus.
- Additional software modes focus on workspace, overhead shots, and whiteboard presentations, enhancing productivity without extra gear.

items.title: Google Calendar now has an Apple Watch app
Tumblr's Move to WordPress and Fediverse Integration on Hold
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary: - Automattic CEO Matt Mullenweg announced that the plan to migrate Tumblr's backend to WordPress is currently *on hold* to prioritize user-focused improvements. - The migration would have enabled Tumblr posts to join the *fediverse* via WordPress' ActivityPub plugin, but this feature is delayed along with the move. - Mullenweg remains interested in the migration for its cleaner structure and says if fediverse integration is urgently needed, it might be implemented directly on Tumblr's codebase.

items.title: The best fitness trackers and watches we’ve tested
Apple Music celebrates 10 years with Replay All Time playlist
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- Apple Music marks its 10th anniversary by launching the *Replay All Time* playlist, letting subscribers revisit their most played songs since 2015.  
- The service will also broadcast the top 500 most-streamed songs from the past decade via Apple Music Radio, with a special countdown and programming.  
- A new 15,000 sq. ft. artist studio in Los Angeles will open this summer, featuring advanced sound and media production facilities.

items.title: Canada drops Big Tech tax to appease Trump
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Canada has *scrapped* its Digital Services Tax targeting US Big Tech companies after President Trump threatened to cut off trade talks.  
- The tax would have imposed a *3% fee* on revenue from online services of firms like Meta, Amazon, and Google, with nearly $3 billion in expected fees.  
- The move aims to *advance trade negotiations* with the US, despite ongoing tariffs and steel surcharges between the countries.

items.title: Apple CarPlay Ultra hands-on: more continuity, less disruption
items.author: Bradley Iger
items.summary:
- *Apple CarPlay Ultra* introduces deeper integration with vehicles, allowing multiple displays and control over climate and drive settings, first debuting in the Aston Martin DBX707.  
- Aston Martin developed its own CarPlay Ultra theme, enhancing personalization and streamlining access to vehicle functions within CarPlay, improving usability with wireless, responsive controls.  
- While CarPlay Ultra offers fresh features and consistency across vehicle models, some automakers resist Apple’s increased control, balancing innovation with in-house software investments.

items.title: Why Automattic CEO Matt Mullenweg went to war over WordPress
items.author: Nilay Patel

items.title: Google is opening its NotebookLM AI tools to students under 18
Apple is reportedly working on a bunch of new XR devices
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Apple plans to significantly expand its XR lineup with seven new head-mounted devices, including *Vision Pro* successors and *smart glasses* with advanced features like voice and gesture controls.  
- An M5-powered Vision Pro headset could launch this year, followed by a smaller, *lighter Vision Air* in 2027, priced lower than the current $3,499 model.  
- Rumored smart glasses debut in 2027 with *AI environmental sensing* and video recording capabilities, while subsequent generations and XR glasses with displays are slated for around 2028.

items.title: Google bets on fusion power as its greenhouse gas emissions grow
Ryan Gosling is not an astronaut in Project Hail Mary’s first trailer
items.author: Andrew Liszewski
items.summary:
- The *first trailer* for *Project Hail Mary*, starring Ryan Gosling as science teacher-turned-astronaut Ryland Grace, has been released by Amazon MGM Studios.  
- The story follows Grace waking up light years from Earth with no memory, tasked with saving humanity by investigating a distant star unaffected by dying suns.  
- Directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller and adapted from Andy Weir's novel, the film blends sci-fi with an alien ally encounter, hitting theaters March 20th, 2026.

items.title: Anker is recalling another five power banks over fire risks
LLMs are optimizing the adult industry
Joby delivers first aircraft to Dubai as air taxi service nears launch
Hundreds of Brother printer models have an unpatchable security flaw
items.author: Jess Weatherbed
items.summary:
- **Eight vulnerabilities** were discovered in 689 Brother printer models, including one critical flaw that *cannot be patched* via firmware updates.  
- The most severe issue, CVE-2024-51978, allows attackers who know the printer’s serial number to generate the default admin password, leading to further exploits.  
- Brother will fix the flaw only in future manufacturing runs; current users must *manually change default passwords* to protect their devices.

items.title: Spotify adds genre personalization to Discover Weekly
items.author: Mia Sato
items.summary:
- Spotify is enhancing its popular *Discover Weekly* playlist by adding genre-specific buttons like pop, R&B, and funk to allow users to customize their music recommendations.
- This update addresses past complaints about repetitive song suggestions and inaccurate genre classifications, alongside a refreshed playlist cover art.
- The change reflects Spotify’s ongoing commitment to *hyper-personalization* through AI-driven features such as an AI DJ and text-to-playlist builder tools.

items.title: Hollywood’s Pivot to AI Video Has a Prompting Problem
items.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore
items.summary:
- Hollywood is rapidly encountering AI-generated videos that often look poor but are hailed as revolutionary by enthusiasts, despite current AI outputs not being film-quality. 
- Bryn Mooser’s Asteria aims to create *ethical* AI tools trained on licensed materials for filmmakers, allowing granular control through model customization, showcased in projects like Cuco's animated short.
- While AI may lower production costs and accelerate filmmaking, it raises concerns about job losses and the loss of creative nuance; Mooser advocates for balanced adoption where AI aids artists without replacing them.

items.title: The unbearable obviousness of AI fitness summaries
items.author: Victoria Song
items.summary:
- AI-generated fitness summaries in apps like Strava, Whoop, and Oura often regurgitate visible data without meaningful insights or personalization.  
- These summaries fail to account for contextual factors such as injuries, weather conditions, and personal health history, limiting their usefulness.  
- Despite user engagement, current AI fitness summaries mostly offer generic feedback, balancing between *speed*, *cost*, *privacy*, and *liability*, but fall short of delivering actionable, personalized advice.

items.title: Pipistrello and the Cursed Yoyo would feel right at home on your GBA
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- *Pipistrello and the Cursed Yoyo* is a charming top-down adventure game featuring Pippit the bat using a yo-yo to battle enemies and solve puzzles, reminiscent of classic Game Boy Advance titles.  
- The game includes a clever contract-based skill tree and a flexible difficulty system, making early combat challenging but customizable for player preference.  
- With pixel art style, nostalgic audio, and inventive yo-yo mechanics, the game blends retro feel with fresh ideas across nearly 10 hours of engaging gameplay.

items.title: ‘We are the media now’: why Tesla’s robotaxis were dominated by Elon Musk superfans
items.author: Mack DeGeurin
items.summary:
- Tesla's recent robotaxi launch event in Austin was dominated by a close-knit group of Elon Musk superfans and influencers who excluded and ridiculed critical journalists, reinforcing a *media echo chamber*.  
- Critics describe this approach as a form of *corporate propaganda* supported by Tesla's sidelining of traditional media and cultivation of loyal fans who promote Tesla's narrative and marketing.  
- While this strategy bolsters Tesla’s image now, experts warn that wider public exposure could challenge the controlled narrative due to the company’s *technical and transparency shortcomings*.

items.title: Apple’s racing movie is finally here
items.author: David Pierce
items.summary:
- The newsletter introduces exciting new content including the surprisingly good *F1 The Movie*, innovative smartphones like the *Fairphone 6* and *Titan 2*, and the meditative upcoming game *Death Stranding 2: On the Beach*.
- Additional highlights include a stylish *Quest 3S Xbox Edition* VR headset, the *Ironheart* series showcasing futuristic tech, and community-shared favorite tools, podcasts, and games.
- David Pierce also shares personal insights, including app organization strategies, a homescreen tour, and recommendations from The Verge team and Installer community, fostering a collaborative and engaging tech culture.

items.title: Supreme Court Ruling Ends Internet Age Verification Ban
items.author: Adi Robertson
items.summary:
- The Supreme Court ruled that states can require *age verification* for adult content online, overturning past decisions and allowing restrictions that minimally impact adult access.
- Concerns remain about *privacy risks* due to data collection inherent in age verification, with fears of security breaches and surveillance in a weakened regulatory environment.
- The ruling may force sites like *Pornhub* to comply with state laws, potentially shrinking adult content availability and triggering broader internet censorship debates.

items.title: Squid Game’s uneven season 3 leaves the door wide open
items.author: Sara Merican
items.summary: - *Squid Game* season 3 delivers intense, brutal games but struggles with tired and uneven worldbuilding, failing to answer intriguing questions about the show's deeper universe. - Strong action sequences and a compelling ensemble cast maintain momentum, but the season is hindered by significant character loss and timid character development. - The season's final moments and emotional episodes offer promise for future spinoffs, leaving many storylines open and engaging viewers for what's next.

items.title: Tesla completes first fully autonomous car delivery
items.author: Andrew J. Hawkins
items.summary:
- Tesla delivered its first car fully autonomously from its Austin Gigafactory to a customer without any human or remote control.  
- Elon Musk announced this milestone was achieved a day earlier than promised, marking progress toward unsupervised Full Self-Driving.  
- Despite Tesla's progress, Waymo has operated fully driverless vehicles on highways for over a year, highlighting ongoing challenges in commercial robotaxi rollouts.

items.title: Kobo Elipsa 2E and Libra Colour Reach Best Prices
items.author: Sheena Vasani
items.summary:
- The **Kobo Elipsa 2E** is discounted to $349.99, offering a 10.3-inch writable screen perfect for note-taking with versatile annotation tools that surpass the Kindle Scribe.  
- The **Kobo Libra Colour** now costs $209.99, featuring a 7-inch color display with physical page-turn buttons and stylus support, delivering a vibrant reading experience and broad file compatibility.  
- Both e-readers support library borrowing via OverDrive and offer unique features like handwriting conversion and color e-ink, broadening options beyond Amazon Kindles.

items.title: Reddit turns 20, and it’s going big on AI
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- Reddit celebrates its 20th anniversary by integrating AI tools like *Reddit Answers*, which combines AI-generated summaries with direct links to human-generated content on Reddit.
- The platform emphasizes the importance of maintaining *trust* by combating AI-generated spam and using AI for moderation and user safety.
- Reddit monetizes its valuable data through partnerships with AI giants like Google and OpenAI, while defending its content rights against misuse, aiming to *preserve its unique community-driven model* amid growing AI competition.

items.title: How extreme heat disproportionately affects Latino neighborhoods
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary:
- *Latino neighborhoods* in California experience *23 more days of extreme heat* annually compared to non-Latino white neighborhoods, exacerbated by less tree canopy and more heat-trapping surfaces.
- The UCLA Latino Climate & Health Dashboard reveals that these communities face *double the air pollution* and asthma-related ER visits, linking heat, pollution, and health disparities.
- Data transparency is crucial as federal climate and equity datasets have been *removed*, making local research and tools vital for policy and community health improvements.

items.title: Did AI companies win a fight with authors? Technically
items.author: Adi Robertson

items.title: Lamborghini Revuelto review: perfect harmony
items.author: Peter Nelson
items.summary: - The 2025 Lamborghini Revuelto is the brand's first plug-in hybrid supercar, combining a 6.5L V12 engine with three electric motors for a total of 1,001 hp and impressive dynamics. - It delivers exceptional performance with 0-60 mph in 2.5 seconds, immersive V12 sound, and enhanced cornering thanks to advanced aerodynamics, a lightweight chassis, and adaptive suspension. - Despite its power, it offers respectable fuel economy (23 MPGe), making it a thrilling yet somewhat efficient hypercar that redefines hybrid high-performance vehicles.

items.title: Facebook is starting to feed its AI with private, unpublished photos
items.author: Tina Nguyen
items.summary:
- Meta is expanding its AI training data to include billions of unpublished photos from users' camera rolls through an opt-in 'cloud processing' feature.  
- This feature allows Meta's AI to analyze private photos, facial features, and other metadata, raising privacy concerns since it's unclear if these images are excluded from AI training.  
- Users can opt out to remove photos after 30 days, but Meta is already offering AI-enhanced suggestions on past photos without explicit user consent, signaling a deeper invasion of privacy beyond posted content.

items.title: US Critical Infrastructure Cyber Vulnerability
items.author: Justine Calma
items.summary: - US critical infrastructure like water, healthcare, and energy are highly vulnerable to cyberattacks due to increased connectivity yet insufficient cybersecurity resources. - State-sponsored groups such as China's Volt Typhoon have compromised water facilities, highlighting the risks amid geopolitical tensions, especially concerning Taiwan and Iran. - Experts advocate for affordable, practical engineering solutions alongside cybersecurity to mitigate damage, emphasizing expanded public-private partnerships and volunteer cyber resilience efforts at state and local levels.

items.title: Logitech says all its webcams work with Nintendo Switch 2, save one
items.author: Sean Hollister
items.summary:
- *Logitech confirms* that all its webcams except the high-end Brio 4K work *out of the box* with the Nintendo Switch 2's new GameChat feature.  
- Manufacturers faced a *mystery* as many webcams initially failed to connect with the Switch 2 due to lack of official guidelines, forcing them to *reverse-engineer* compatibility and update firmware.  
- Other brands like Elgato and Ugreen are also updating webcams for compatibility, while some users report unofficial Brio 4K support via firmware downgrades, albeit at *risk*.

items.title: The Nothing Phone 3 might have the weirdest camera design out there
items.author: Jay Peters
items.summary:
- The *Nothing Phone 3* is rumored to feature a translucent back with a uniquely *weird camera layout*, including two cameras side by side and one isolated in a phone corner.
- This design contrasts typical smartphone cameras that are neatly aligned in triangles or bars, presenting potentially the boldest layout yet, reminiscent but bolder than the Nothing 3A Pro.
- Official teases, including a 50MP periscope lens image and a "Glyph Matrix" feature, suggest these designs are authentic; the phone will be revealed on July 1st alongside new headphones.

items.title: Best Gaming Laptops Tested by The Verge
items.author: Antonio G. Di Benedetto
items.summary: - The Asus ROG Zephyrus G14 remains the top pick for a balanced *gaming laptop* combining portability, OLED display, and solid performance, albeit with some heat and noise under load. - The MSI Titan 18 HX, though *astronomically expensive*, offers unmatched power with an 18-inch 4K Mini LED display, top-tier CPU and GPU options, making it the *most powerful* gaming laptop available. - Mid-to-high-tier laptops like the Asus ROG Strix Scar 16 and Lenovo Legion Pro 7i provide excellent gaming performance, lots of ports, and strong displays with RTX 5080 GPUs at more accessible prices, but share typical gaming laptop compromises like weight and battery life.

items.title: Runway to Enable AI-Generated Video Games
items.author: Alex Heath
items.summary:
- Runway, known for AI in Hollywood, is expanding into the gaming industry with plans to release AI-generated video games later this year.  
- The company is developing a chat interface for text and image generation with gaming capabilities coming, and is in talks with gaming companies to use their tech and data.  
- CEO Cristóbal Valenzuela compares the gaming AI adoption to Hollywood's experience and values the company's independence despite acquisition interest from Meta.

items.title: Trump's 'big beautiful bill' could slow down 6GHz Wi-Fi
items.author: Jennifer Pattison Tuohy
items.summary:
- The Senate’s budget bill, supported by Donald Trump, proposes auctioning 800 MHz of the 6GHz unlicensed spectrum to mobile carriers, potentially *slowing Wi-Fi speeds* by reducing available bandwidth for Wi-Fi 6E and Wi-Fi 7 devices.
- This spectrum reallocation could generate government revenue but faces criticism from tech companies like Apple, Amazon, and Meta, who warn it threatens *future tech growth* in AI, AR/VR, and smart home innovations.
- While proponents argue that auctioning the spectrum prepares carriers for the next wireless leap, some carriers like AT&T currently see *no urgent need* for more spectrum, raising questions about the bill’s impact on consumers.

items.title: Eufy’s Omni C20 mopping robovac is $300 off for a limited time
items.author: Brandon Russell
items.summary:
- The **Eufy Omni C20** is a robot vacuum and mop combo with automated features like emptying, washing, drying, and refilling the mop, currently discounted by $300 to $399.98 for a limited time.
- It has dual sweeping and mopping modules with 180 rotations per minute, 7,000Pa suction, and a pro-detangle comb to handle dirt, tough stains, and pet hair, but lacks obstacle avoidance.
- Other notable deals include the Super Mario Odyssey digital game, BioLite Solar Site Lights, and Apple Watch Series 10 at discounted prices.

items.title: Google's carbon emissions just went up again
items.author: Emma Roth
items.summary:
- Google's carbon emissions increased by **11 percent** last year, reaching 11.5 million metric tons, a **51 percent increase since 2019**, due to AI expansion.  
- The company's total emissions, including supply chain and peripheral activities, are around **15.2 million metric tons**, equivalent to nearly 40 gas-fired power plants.  
- External challenges like AI's unpredictable energy needs, policy changes, and slow carbon-free energy rollout complicate Google's climate goals despite data center emission reductions.

items.title: Where to Buy microSD Express Cards for Nintendo Switch 2
items.author: Cameron Faulkner
items.summary:
- The Nintendo Switch 2 requires *microSD Express* cards for storing and playing games, offering a 4.4x faster data transfer than previous microSD cards compatible with the original Switch.  
- These microSD Express cards are notably *more expensive*, with typical prices over $50 for 256GB, and up to $200 for 1TB, although Walmart's Onn brand provides some more affordable options.  
- The new Switch 2 includes 256GB of built-in storage, potentially reducing the urgency for an upgrade, and multiple brands like Samsung, PNY, Onn, Sandisk, GameStop, and Lexar offer compatible cards currently available online.

items.title: The best deals on 4K TVs
items.author: Brandt Ranj
items.summary:
- The article highlights great *2025 discounts* on various 4K TVs including models from Samsung, TCL, Panasonic, Amazon, Hisense, and LG, tailored for different budgets and needs.
- It features *highlights* like Samsung Q8F's 120Hz QLED panel, TCL QM7K's bright QD-Mini LED, Panasonic Z85's budget OLED, and LG G5 OLED for premium gaming and cinematic experience.
- Budget options include Amazon Fire TV 4-Series and Hisense QD7, both offering solid performance for their price, with features like HDR support and AI upscaling.
